user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_GetReturnStatus:
```c
int OS_BSP_GetReturnStatus(void)
{
    int retcode;

    switch (OS_BSP_Global.AppStatus)
    {
        case OS_SUCCESS:
            /* translate OS_SUCCESS to the system EXIT_SUCCESS value (usually 0) */
            retcode = EXIT_SUCCESS;
            break;

        case OS_ERROR:
            /* translate OS_ERROR to the system EXIT_FAILURE value (usually 1) */
            retcode = EXIT_FAILURE;
            break;

        default:
            /* any other value will be passed through (implementation-defined) */
            /* Range is limited to 0-127, however */
            retcode = OS_BSP_Global.AppStatus & 0x7F;
            break;
    }

    return retcode;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in this function. The code uses only standard C constructs (function definition, local int, switch/case/default/break, bitwise &, return). EXIT_SUCCESS and EXIT_FAILURE are standard macros from <stdlib.h>, not compiler extensions. There are no vendor-specific keywords or attributes (for example __attribute__, __asm, typeof, statement-expressions, nested functions, or other known GCC/MSVC/Clang extensions), no inline assembly, no variable-length arrays, no designated initializers or compound literals, and no other nonstandard syntax. The comment about implementation-defined behavior relates to platform-defined semantics of exit status values, not a language extension. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
